Wasfia wanted to change this in Bangladesh. She combined her two passions, mountaineering and human rights, to make a difference. Wasfia started climbing while working on humanitarian projects in Tibet and Nepal. Bangladesh is a flat country, so most people have never seen a mountain before. Her campaign seems to be working. Many people, including those in Bangladesh and around the world, are paying attention.

Most people think that countries with little money and poor leaders are in a very bad situation. They suffer from poverty, are ruled by dictators, and have little chance of real change. However, this is not true. A great change is happening. In the last 20 years, over 700 million people have become richer and left poverty behind. Every year, six million fewer children die from diseases. More girls are in school now than ever before. Millions of people have access to clean water.

Many managers try to give positive feedback by putting it between two positive comments. However, this can make employees feel that positive feedback is not important. It's better to give feedback that is both positive and negative, but focuses on the good work. This way, the positive feedback is seen as a reward for doing well, and helps to encourage good performance.

I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots.  Many people think of the movie Terminator and imagine a machine that kills humans.  But in reality, machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already used to kill with little human help.  Next, we'll have autonomous machines, like'murderbots', which will decide who to kill on their own.  This is not acceptable to me.  It's a big risk for humanity.  We need to be careful about what we ask machines to do.

More people are learning English than any other language. In fact, English is spoken in more countries than any other language. But Chinese has the most native speakers. There is no clear connection between the number of native speakers and the number of learners. However, there is a stronger link between the number of learners and the number of countries where people speak the language.

Your manager stops you and tells you to talk about your recent project. You worry about it all weekend. On Monday morning, you go to her office. She starts by saying you did good work on the project. You wonder if this is just praise to start a conversation. You know how feedback usually works: say something nice, say what you really need to say, say something nice again.

A fast rock album called Born in the USA has emotional lyrics. The catchy rock melodies make powerful songs. But behind these melodies are stories about the dark side of the American dream. Many songs talk about ordinary people's struggles. They feel bitter and angry because they don't have wealth or success. The song Glory Days is about people who were young and successful in a small town. Downbound Train tells the story of a young man who lost his job and became poor. It's easy to imagine that the artist wrote about people he knew. The artist might have written about his own life if he hadn't become famous. This album shows that the Boss is a very talented musician.

Lewis wants the world to have more marine protected areas. He wants these areas to cover 10% of the world's oceans. This is to stop people from damaging the environment. Lewis has seen the damage with his own eyes. He has swum over coral reefs that are dying because of the warmer water. He has also seen underwater deserts in the Red Sea. These deserts are empty of life and full of plastic. Lewis thinks that nature can recover if we give it space. But time is running out. We must start taking care of our seas if we don't want to have a big problem soon. If we don't act now, the damage will be too much to solve.

Terrie Sharp is a very successful author. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. Terrie was born on a housing estate in Glasgow, a city with a high crime rate. When she was young, she had to be careful and stay out of trouble. She learned to open car doors with her knife. Luckily, she used her knowledge for good and wrote books instead of causing trouble. Today, she talks on TV and at writing conferences in the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? 
We are making progress. We are living longer, healthier lives. We are also happier. 
However, Steven Pinker says that the big problem is that our way of thinking is under threat. 
He says that people are being fooled by tribalism, fatalism and distrust. 
This is bad for important institutions like democracy and co-operation. 
If we do not think clearly and rationally, we may damage these institutions. 
This could have serious consequences. 
We need to be careful and think critically. 
We must protect our institutions and values. 
We must also work together to achieve our goals. 
Co-operation is essential for a better future.

Older horror films often showed characters in a desperate situation. They had no way to call for help or the police. Now, with mobile phones, it's a bit easier to believe that they can't get a signal. So, how can filmmakers keep the suspense? One solution is to make the phone battery die at a crucial moment. Another way is to make the hero have no signal at all. Or, the hero's phone battery could die when they are about to make a call. This creates suspense and makes the story more exciting.

In the 1950s, Central American banana growers were in trouble. Their main banana, the Gros Michel, was dying. Now, it's happening again with its successor, the Cavendish. The Gros Michel was a popular banana due to its thick skin and sweet taste. It grew well in Central America's plantations. United Fruit, a major grower and exporter, produced its bananas in a very efficient way. It cloned shoots from the plant stems instead of growing new plants from seeds. United Fruit packed its bananas tightly in the fields.

Spider venom is present in most spiders. It helps them catch their food by stunning or killing it, not by hurting humans. Most spiders do not harm humans. Only 25 species can hurt humans. Their bites can be painful, but usually not deadly. Australia's Sydney funnel-web spider has not killed anyone since the development of anti-venom in 1981. However, be careful when you touch hairy spiders, like tarantulas. If they feel threatened, they can defend themselves by releasing irritating hairs into the air. These hairs can stick to your skin or eyes if you touch them.

Horror movies have a common theme. This theme is called "the last girl." It is popular in horror movies from the 20th century. The story usually starts with a group of teenagers having fun. The story ends with most of them dead, but one girl survives. The main character, a girl, is often weak and shy at the beginning. However, by the end of the story, she is strong and brave. She is usually the last one standing.

If we want to know how we can speak complex language, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. It's not just about brain size; it's about what else our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. Unfortunately, there are few physical clues. Our ancestors' artefacts don't show us what speech they were capable of making. However, we can see from the remains of early humans that their mouths, throats and tongues developed. About 100,000 years ago, humans were able to create complex sounds. Before then, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether early humans used simple or complex sounds to communicate.

Society tells us that girls should study arts and humanities, and boys should study maths and physics. However, this is not a natural choice. The problem is that there are not enough positive female role models in science. Cartoons and stories often show scientists as men. They also portray scientists as strange, lonely, and not good at social skills. These are not true, but they can make girls think that science is not a good career choice. If girls saw more positive female scientists, they would feel more confident and want to study science more.

The Scallion is a weekly newspaper that gives away copies in faculty buildings. About 10,000 students read it. The newspaper is written and produced by students. Many students value The Scallion for entertainment, culture, and work experience. However, printing the newspaper is expensive. Some students have trouble getting a copy because they have to physically go to the university. This causes an environmental problem too. Many copies end up on the ground.

At Girox Foods, we are experiencing a high employee turnover rate of about 12 per cent every year. This is higher than the industry average of seven per cent. Our goal is to investigate why employees are not satisfied and find ways to improve their working experience and keep them from leaving the company.

I agree with what the speaker said. Many people feel more isolated even though they are connected to others. I think this is true for people my age who grew up without technology. We know how to be alone and it's okay to be alone. However, people under 20 are different. They spend so much time communicating with others that they rarely feel alone and don't learn how to enjoy their own company. Furthermore, they learn how to talk to others through messages, which can be changed or edited, rather than learning how to have real conversations in real time with the person in front of them.

Do not always respond to positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback are given together, people start to ignore the positives. We should give positive feedback sometimes just for the sake of it, and avoid criticizing constructively.
